items.title: Readers reply: What is the biggest missed opportunity in history?
items.summary:
- Readers discuss historical missed opportunities, including EMI passing on The Beatles.
- The impact of the Blair government's policies on social housing is highlighted.
- Concerns are raised about ignoring climate change warnings from scientists.
- The effect of the internet on misinformation is noted, along with suggestions for accountability.
- Bernie Sanders not receiving the 2016 Democratic nomination is mentioned as a significant missed chance.
- Historical events, such as France's inaction during Hitler's remilitarization of the Rhineland, are discussed as missed opportunities.

items.title: Skype shutdown surfaces sweet memories: ‘I proposed marriage’
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Microsoft announced the shutdown of Skype, set for 5 May 2025, marking the end of an era for the video chatting platform.
- Experts noted Skype's neglect by Microsoft as a precursor to its demise, citing lack of integration with Microsoft's other services.
- Users shared nostalgic memories, including proposals and connections made possible through the platform, highlighting its role in maintaining long-distance relationships.
- Tributes celebrated the impact of Skype on personal and professional lives, particularly during times of isolation or geographical separation.
- Creative expressions inspired by Skype, such as music compositions and personal anecdotes, resonated among former users.

items.title: Who bought this smoked salmon? How ‘AI agents’ will change the internet (and shopping lists)
items.summary:
- OpenAI's new AI agent, Operator, can autonomously shop online using a grocery list.
- Operator is accessible to UK users and can complete tasks like searching and ordering items from supermarket websites.
- AI agents are considered the next step in technology, helping automate mundane tasks, though they are still experimental.
- Limitations include needing user intervention for login and handling sensitive information.
- Users experienced mixed results with grocery orders, sometimes receiving incorrect items.
- The technology aims to evolve, enabling agents to perform more tasks and learning user preferences over time.

items.title: Internet shutdowns at record high in Africa as access ‘weaponised’
items.summary:
- Digital blackouts reached a record high in 2024 in Africa, with 21 shutdowns in 15 countries.
- This surpasses the previous record of 19 shutdowns noted in 2020 and 2021.
- Shutdowns primarily occurred in response to conflicts, protests, political instability, and elections.
- Countries involved included Comoros, Guinea-Bissau, Mauritius, Burundi, Ethiopia, Equatorial Guinea, and Kenya.
- The trend of increasing shutdowns was noted globally, with 296 across 54 countries in 2024.
- The African Commission on Human and Peoples’ Rights passed a resolution in March 2024 to address this issue, but shutdowns have continued.

items.title: Stalked: how a relentless campaign of online abuse came to derail one woman’s life
Skype got shouted down by Teams and Zoom. But it revolutionised human connection
items.author: John Naughton
items.summary:
- Microsoft has decided to terminate Skype on May 5, 2025, moving users to Microsoft Teams.
- Skype was founded in 2003 and became the first successful VoIP service, boasting 100 million users by 2006.
- Despite being revolutionary for digital communication, Skype was sidelined by Microsoft in favor of Teams, especially during the pandemic when remote work surged.
- Skype's introduction significantly transformed telephony, enabling free global communication, which was previously expensive and limited under traditional phone systems.

items.title: Virtual reality in solitary confinement isn’t a Black Mirror episode. It’s happening in California
items.summary:
- Samantha Tovar, known as Royal, experiences virtual reality (VR) for the first time in a California prison, providing a mental escape from solitary confinement.
- The seven-day intensive VR program includes immersive scenes from daily life and adventure, aimed at processing emotions through art exercises.
- Creative Acts, the organization behind the program, uses arts as a resource for behavioral change among participants. Plans to expand beyond California are hampered by funding issues.

items.title: Meet-cutes, boys’ bedrooms and buff bodies: meet the people behind TikTok’s viral vox pop accounts
items.author: Rachel Coster, Jeremy Bernstein, Aaron Feinberg, Victor Lee, Simon Squibb, Mark Langowski
items.summary:
- Rachel Coster's TikTok account, @boyroomshow, explores boys' messy bedrooms and domesticity issues.  
- Comedian Coster conceptualized the show during the Hollywood actor's strike, now with 40 episodes highlighting boys' often neglected living spaces.  
- Meet-cutes NYC, run by Aaron Feinberg, Jeremy Bernstein, and Victor Lee, interviews couples about their relationships, now boasting 1.8 million followers.  
- The group is expanding to London and plans to hire interviewers in Europe, having captured around 7,000 couples' stories.  
- Simon Squibb uses TikTok to help people achieve their dreams, having invested in 79 businesses, proving the power of social media for positive impact.  
- Mark Langowski asks fitness questions on the street, revealing compelling stories behind everyday people's workout routines.

items.title: ‘Major brand worries’: Just how toxic is Elon Musk for Tesla?
items.summary:
- Tesla registrations in Germany fell 76% to 1,429 last month amid rising electric vehicle registrations overall.
- Elon Musk's support for Germany's Alternative für Deutschland has tarnished Tesla's brand image.
- Tesla's valuation is closely tied to Musk's political activities, raising concerns over potential long-term effects on sales and brand reputation.
- Activists have staged protests against Musk and Tesla, indicating growing public dissatisfaction.
- In January 2025, Tesla reported a sales decline, with global projections suggesting a need for customer retention in an increasingly competitive market.

items.title: Martha Lane Fox Critiques Elon Musk and Diversity Issues on International Women’s Day
items.author: Martha Lane Fox
items.summary:
- Martha Lane Fox expresses strong criticism of Elon Musk, calling him 'horrendous' and highlighting concerns over his influence on diversity initiatives.
- The US government under Trump has rolled back diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) initiatives, impacting many companies.
- Fox warns that neglecting diversity will lead to economic and social inequality, emphasizing that companies with diversity are better positioned for business success.
- She notes that progress in gender equality in the workplace is stagnating, with the UK now at its lowest ranking for workplace gender equality among large economies in a decade.
- Fox stresses the importance of keeping diversity issues visible and reports on progress, instead of relying solely on government regulation for targets.

items.title: Trump to host crypto leaders after creating strategic reserve of bitcoin
items.summary:
- Cryptocurrency industry leaders to meet with Donald Trump to discuss making the U.S. the "crypto capital of the world".
- Trump signed an executive order creating a strategic reserve of cryptocurrency, set to include bitcoin.
- Key attendees include Michael Saylor, Zach Witkoff, and Vlad Tenev, with discussions focused on the strategic reserve's details.
- The reserve will utilize forfeited bitcoin from federal assets, as stated by White House crypto czar David Sacks.
- Participants express optimism for collaborative regulation under the current administration, with various views on the included cryptocurrencies.
- The meeting aims to clarify regulatory scrutiny and the approval process for exchange-traded funds.

items.title: Crypto giant Tether CEO on cooperating with Trump administration: ‘We’ve never been shady’
items.author: Paolo Ardoino
items.summary:
- Paolo Ardoino, CEO of Tether, reflects on the company's evolution from conflict with regulators to cooperation.
- Tether is now the 17th largest holder of US government debt, with $140 billion in assets backing its stablecoin at a one-to-one ratio with the dollar.
- Ardoino emphasizes Tether's transparency and cooperation with law enforcement, contrasting past regulatory hostility.
- Recent discussions include a push for thorough audits of stablecoins to ensure their backing and compliance with regulations.
- The company has recovered stolen funds and claims to be more transparent and efficient than traditional banks in handling illicit activities.
- Ardoino expresses optimism about upcoming regulations under the new administration and the importance of maintaining the US's currency dominance.

items.title: ‘It would be seen as political’: why the Royal Society is torn over Elon Musk
items.summary:
- The Royal Society is experiencing a crisis over fellow Elon Musk's conduct, sparking debates about its role in society.
- Numerous scientists demand an investigation into Musk's behavior since his election as a fellow in 2018, citing violations of the Society's code of conduct.
- Critics point to Musk's controversial remarks and actions, including incendiary comments about UK politicians and funding cuts affecting research.
- Calls for Musk's expulsion have come from prominent figures like Nobel laureate Geoffrey Hinton, highlighting concern over his influence on scientific institutions.
- Despite internal pressures and an open letter from over 3,500 members, the Royal Society has remained largely silent on the matter.
- Tensions exist within the fellowship regarding whether political opinions should affect membership status, complicating Musk's case further.
- The Society is debating potential actions while maintaining confidentiality around individual conduct issues, raising questions about its accountability.

items.title: Atomfall, the survival game that draws from classic British sci-fi
items.summary:
- Set in 1962, around Windscale nuclear power station after a meltdown.
- Players must survive against cultists, monsters, and dangerous creatures while exploring a quarantine zone.
- Inspired by classic British sci-fi themes, drawing from works like Dr Who and The Wicker Man.
- Gameplay involves scavenging, crafting makeshift weapons, and stealth mechanics.
- Various enemies include territorial bees and a gang of druids.
- Skill points can be used to enhance stealth, health, and combat efficiency.
- Atomfall releases on 27 March 2025.

items.title: Could Elon Musk’s newfound political influence help him finally crack India?
items.summary:
- Elon Musk seeks to enter the Indian market with Tesla and Starlink.
- Musk recently met Indian PM Narendra Modi to discuss collaboration in innovation and space exploration.
- India’s high tariffs on electric vehicles have hindered Tesla’s entrance, but a potential tax break could facilitate it.
- Starlink aims to tap into India’s growing satellite internet market, estimated to reach $1.9 billion by 2030.
- Regulatory hurdles may challenge Starlink’s operations in India due to security concerns linked to foreign control.
- Indian government actions hint at a favorable stance towards Starlink following Trump's reelection.

items.title: If we’re going to rank the hottest video game characters, let’s not be boring about it
items.summary:
- Lara Croft is ranked as the second most attractive video game character, behind Geralt of Rivia from The Witcher.  
- The rankings are based on the golden ratio method used by a gambling site, Casino Days.  
- The article critiques the obsession with the attractiveness of video game characters, suggesting characters like Guybrush Threepwood and Mario are overlooked.  
- Princess Zelda is controversially named the least attractive character, raising issues of sexism in the rankings.  
- The piece calls for a broader understanding of attractiveness beyond mere physical symmetry, emphasizing personality traits like honesty.

items.title: It’s the age of regret: gen Z grew up glued to their screens, and missed the joy of being human | Gaby Hinsliff
BBC News to create AI department to offer more personalised content
items.author: Deborah Turness
items.summary:
- BBC News is establishing a new AI department focused on personalized content to better engage under-25 audiences.
- Chief executive Deborah Turness cited significant challenges in the news landscape, including news avoidance and digital competition.
- The department aims to curate stories based on user preferences and ensure quality journalism across different platforms.
- BBC commits to using AI in a way that aligns with their public service values, ensuring accuracy and fairness.
- Turness highlighted the BBC News app's success, overtaking Apple News as the top UK news app.

items.title: The English schools looking to dispel ‘doom and gloom’ around AI
Maximum points: what is the most influential video game ever?
‘Trump Gaza’ AI video intended as political satire, says creator
items.author: Solo Avital, Ariel Vromen
items.summary:
- The creator of the ‘Trump Gaza’ video, Solo Avital, intended it as political satire.  
- The AI-generated video shows a surreal image of Gaza as a luxurious paradise with Trump and Netanyahu.  
- Avital created the video in under eight hours using AI tools and shared it with friends before its viral spread.  
- Trump shared the video on his Truth Social account on February 26, 2025, without any context.  
- Avital expressed surprise at the reactions and noted the media's portrayal of AI-generated content.  
- Hany Farid, a professor, emphasized the potential dangers of AI-generated videos misused for misinformation.

items.title: Safer phones bill aimed at young teens watered down after minister opposition
items.summary:
- Campaigners sought a bill to ban addictive smartphone algorithms for young teens, but it has been diluted.
- The revised bill will focus on research rather than immediate legislative changes.
- Key proposals, like raising internet adulthood age and banning mobile phones in schools, have been removed due to ministerial opposition.

items.title: Ban mobile phones in schools across Europe, says Danish expert
items.summary:
- Rasmus Meyer, chair of Denmark’s wellbeing commission, advocates for a ban on mobile phones in schools across Europe to counteract digital platform colonization.
- The commission released a report recommending legislation to prohibit phones in schools and after-school clubs in Denmark, emphasizing benefits like improved attention spans and social interactions among children.
- Meyer suggests that EU regulation is needed, highlighting the urgency to address the negative impacts of technology on children's self-esteem and attention.

items.title: UK watchdog drops competition review of Microsoft’s OpenAI partnership
items.summary:
- The UK’s Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) will not investigate Microsoft's partnership with OpenAI, citing lack of de facto control.
- Microsoft, with a $13bn investment in OpenAI, holds 'material influence' but has not changed to de facto control since 2019.
- The decision comes amidst concerns about regulatory pressures and aims to avoid a chilling effect on business confidence.
- Recent CMA investigations have targeted Google for search dominance and Apple's influence on mobile platforms.
- Microsoft recently participated in a $6.6bn funding round for OpenAI, valuing the company at $157bn.

items.title: Judge denies Musk’s initial bid to halt OpenAI’s for-profit shift but sets trial for fall
items.summary:
- A US judge denied Elon Musk's request to pause OpenAI's transition to a for-profit model.
- A trial is scheduled for fall 2025 to address ongoing legal disputes between Musk and OpenAI.
- Musk accuses OpenAI of straying from its original mission, while OpenAI maintains its actions are necessary for competition and capital.
- This ruling comes after Musk's consortium's failed acquisition attempt of OpenAI valued at $97.4 billion.

items.title: The Nintendo Switch revolutionised on-the-go gaming – can the PlayStation Portal do the same?
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Capcom’s Monster Hunter Wilds sold **8 million units** in three days.
- The **PlayStation Portal**, costing £200, streams games from the PS5 but has mixed usability experiences.
- Despite excellent performance at home, streaming quality on hotel wifi was poor.
- The **Nintendo Switch**, released eight years ago, is considered the **gold standard** for portable gaming due to its offline capabilities.
- Anticipation builds for the **Nintendo Switch 2** event on **April 2**, hinting at continued non-internet reliant gaming solutions.

items.title: Sammy J: the 10 funniest things I have ever seen (on the internet)
items.summary:
- Sammy J reminisces about the internet's impact on humor and culture.
- Lists 10 funny videos that showcase the bizarre and entertaining side of internet content.
- Highlights moments of pure comedic gold, such as a man trying not to burp and failing spectacularly.
- Discusses the value of unrefined, amateur-style internet content in contrast to professional production values.
- Encourages readers to appreciate the absurdity and spontaneity of online humor.

items.title: Two Point Museum review – curate your own fun in this museum management game
items.summary:
- The game features whimsical satire about managing a museum, including absurd characters like a scuba diver thief.
- Players must hire various staff, manage exhibits, and strategize to generate visitor donations.
- Allows for diverse themes and exhibits, blending different eras and elements.
- The graphics and mechanics have significantly improved, enhancing player experience and creativity.

items.title: They wanted to save us from a dark AI future. Then six people were killed
items.summary:
- Ziz, a programmer and central figure in a double homicide, faked her drowning and was arrested in 2025.
- The story intertwines multiple killings, starting with a shootout that left a federal agent dead in January 2025.
- Ziz was linked with a group known as 'Zizians', who shared radical ideas influenced by AI and philosophy, ultimately leading to violence.

items.title: Tesla’s UK sales rise despite threat of backlash over Musk’s political role
items.summary:
- Tesla sales in the UK rose by 20.7% year on year in February, with almost 4,000 cars sold.
- Model 3 and Model Y ranked as the second and third most popular cars sold, respectively.
- Tesla's market share increased from 3.75% in February 2024 to 4.6% in February 2025, despite a 1% decline in the overall market.
- Demand for electric vehicles surged by almost 42% year on year as buyers sought to avoid a new tax coming into effect in April.
- Concerns exist about a potential backlash against Tesla due to Elon Musk's political influences, including support for far-right politics in Europe.
- Sales of new Tesla cars in Europe nearly halved in January, dropping market share to 1%.
- In China, early February data shows a 49% decline in exports and retail sales, linked to a model changeover.
- Preliminary data for February suggests a rebound in US sales, with approximately 42,000 cars sold, up 14% year on year.

items.title: ‘Shadow fleets’ and subaquatic sabotage: are Europe’s undersea internet cables under attack?
items.summary:
- Europe is on high alert due to a series of outages affecting undersea cables and pipelines.
- The article provides a visual guide explaining the incidents and responses.
- Ongoing concerns about potential attacks on critical digital infrastructure.

items.title: Some British firms ‘stuck in neutral’ over AI, says Microsoft UK boss
items.author: Darren Hardman
items.summary:
- A Microsoft survey showed over half of UK executives believe their organizations lack a formal AI strategy.
- Many organizations remain in the experimentation phase with AI rather than deploying it effectively.
- Microsoft advocates for the use of AI in workplaces with products like Copilot Studio, aimed at improving productivity.
- AI could potentially displace up to 3 million jobs in the UK, but the net loss is expected to be minimal due to new job roles creation.
- Proposed reforms to copyright law would allow AI training on copyrighted work, met with criticism from creative industries.

items.title: Revealed: the scammers who conned savers out of $35m using fake celebrity ads
items.summary:
- An organized network from Georgia scammed savers out of $35m through fake celebrity ads on Facebook and Google.
- Prominent figures like Martin Lewis, Zoe Ball, and Ben Fogle appeared in deepfake videos promoting fraudulent schemes.
- UK victims accounted for about £9m of the total loss, with calls continuing to target victims recently.
- A data leak exposing scam operations revealed the extensive scale of the fraud and the details of victims.
- New laws from the UK government aim to combat such scams, though full enforcement is delayed until next year.
- Cases of APP fraud increased by 12% in 2023, highlighting the growing concern over online scams.
- Revolut emerged as a key bank mentioned in scam operations, indicating the role of newer digital banking services in these frauds.

items.title: Why Elon Musk is targeting a free tax-filing software
items.summary:
- Elon Musk has targeted the General Services Administration (GSA), specifically its tech division known as 18F, which manages a free tax-filing software, IRS Direct File.
- Musk tweeted he had 'deleted' IRS Direct File, although it remained operational.
- His actions are expected to financially affect American taxpayers through increased costs and legal expenses due to controversial staff terminations within the federal government.

items.title: When video game age ratings go wrong
items.summary:
- Balatro, a card game, initially rated 3+ was later reclassified to 18+ due to its portrayal of gambling.
- The game became a bestseller since its release in February 2024, but faced significant distribution issues post reclassification.
- After appeals, Balatro was finally re-rated to 12+ a year later, prompting changes in the Pan-European Game Information (Pegi) classification system for games depicting gambling.

items.title: Power struggle: will Brazil’s booming datacentre industry leave ordinary people in the dark?
items.summary:
- Deodato Alves da Silva's community in Amazonas state struggles with frequent electricity shortages, impacting income from fruit farming.
- Brazil has over 1.3 million people living with limited electricity, despite having one of the cleanest power grids globally, led by hydropower.
- The country is experiencing a datacentre boom, with 46 new facilities under construction, as multinationals invest due to growing digitalization demands.
- Major firms like Amazon and Microsoft have announced significant investments in Brazilian datacentres to support cloud computing and AI applications.
- Experts warn that increasing datacentre energy and water consumption could strain Brazil's energy grid, especially amid climate-induced drought conditions.
- The government remains optimistic about the potential of a renewable energy future, despite concerns over energy poverty affecting millions.

items.title: Typewriters, stinky carpets and crazy press trips: what it was like working on video game mags in the 1980s
items.summary:
- In the summer of 1985, the author recalls attending the Commodore computer show and meeting Zzap!64 reviewer Julian Rignall.
- The mid-80s saw magazines like Crash and Zzap!64 become crucial sources of gaming news due to scarce information on developers.
- Publications operated in cramped, outdated offices, with many relying on a low-tech, labor-intensive production process involving typewriters and physical layouts.
- Newer magazines like Your Sinclair embraced irreverence and personality-driven journalism, establishing strong connections with readers.
- As home computers waned, the focus began to shift towards consoles and Japanese gaming culture by the end of the 1980s.
- Rignall's memoir offers insights into the industry's evolution and the creative chaos behind early video game journalism.

items.title: Haggle, bundle or switch: how to get the best UK broadband deal
items.summary:
- True fibre broadband speeds can be very high; paying for only what you need is advised.
- HD streaming requires different upload speeds; compare speeds based on your usage.
- Current providers often raise prices after contracts end; haggling can yield better deals.
- Consider using comparison sites like Uswitch to negotiate better pricing.
- Switching account holders may allow access to new customer deals, but can involve down time.
- Moving to a new provider could provide a better offer; use services like One Touch Switch for minimal downtime.
- Bundling services may reduce overall costs but can limit flexibility in the future.
- Ditching the landline can save on rental costs, as modern broadband doesn't require one.
- Purchasing your own router may be more cost-effective in the long run than renting from providers.
- 5G and satellite broadband are alternatives if fixed-line options are unsatisfactory; however, costs and performance vary.

items.title: Tightly choreographed Two Sessions opens in Beijing as the world order roils
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Thousands of delegates arrive in Beijing for the annual parliamentary session known as the Two Sessions.
- Heightened security is noticeable with increased police presence and random ID scans at busy locations.
- China's economic situation is tense, with consumer goods sales down 4% in Chaoyang district and rising unemployment.
- Analysts are watching for Li Qiang's government work report, particularly the GDP target for 2025.
- China's economic strategy is shifting from a focus on GDP growth to investment in innovation and high-tech sectors, with AI firm DeepSeek leading the way.

items.title: The LA Times published an op-ed warning of AI’s dangers. It also published its AI tool’s reply
items.author: Rachel Antell, Stephanie Jenkins, Jennifer Petrucelli
items.summary:
- A Los Angeles Times op-ed discusses dangers of AI, specifically in documentary filmmaking.
- The op-ed’s authors argue unregulated AI could undermine the credibility of visuals.
- The LA Times's AI tool, 'Insight', provided a counter response labeling the op-ed as politically 'center-left'.
- The AI's response defends AI's role in democratizing storytelling and suggests technological advancements can coexist with regulations.
- Critics express concerns that AI-generated analyses may further erode trust in media rather than enhance it.
- The AI-generated content is not reviewed by LA Times journalists prior to publication.

items.title: Ghost hunting, pornography and interactive art: the weird afterlife of Xbox Kinect
items.summary:
- Kinect was released in 2010, selling 1m units in the first 10 days and remains the fastest-selling gaming peripheral ever.
- After initial hype, it faced issues like a lack of games and was discontinued in 2017 but found use in various fields, including interactive art and robotics.
- Used by ghost hunters as an SLS camera to detect figures not visible to the naked eye, leading to interest in paranormal activity.

items.title: Mental health crisis ‘means youth is no longer one of happiest times of life’
items.author: Jean Twenge, David Blanchflower
items.summary:
- A new paper by Jean Twenge and David Blanchflower indicates a mental health crisis among youth in six English-speaking countries.
- The traditional U-shape of happiness has shifted, with increased wellbeing in older age instead of during youth.
- Surveys show that young people's life satisfaction and happiness have declined over the past decade, especially for young women.
- The rise of smartphones and social media coincides with this trend, leading to increased isolation and reduced social interactions amongst the youth.
- Blanchflower warns this could create a 'lost generation' due to factors like cyberbullying, body shaming, and withdrawal from social activities.
- The UN is considering this issue as a global crisis, with ongoing research to understand its broader implications.

items.title: UK watchdog to investigate TikTok and Reddit over use of children’s data
items.summary:
- The UK’s Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO) is launching an investigation into TikTok, Reddit, and Imgur regarding their data practices affecting children.
- The investigation will focus on TikTok’s use of personal information from 13- to 17-year-olds for content recommendations and the age assurance measures used by Reddit and Imgur.
- The ICO aims to assess the platforms' compliance with the children's code for online privacy established in 2021, with an emphasis on protecting children from harmful content and data practices.

items.title: UK unions call for action to protect creative industry workers as AI develops
items.summary:
- Unions urge action to protect creative workers amid AI changes.
- TUC demands transparency in AI training data and fair compensation for artists.
- Calls for an independent regulator to oversee AI integration in society.
- TUC general secretary warns against exploitation by tech bosses if regulations are not established.
- Proposals for better protection of creative industries are needed to safeguard the sector's future.

items.title: The best air fryers, tried and tested for crisp and crunch
items.summary:
- Air fryers have evolved from single-drawer designs to various configurations, providing options like grilling, roasting, and baking.
- The article reviews top air fryers including:
  - **Best overall**: Tefal Dual Easy Fry XXL EY942BG0 for £149.99 at Amazon.
  - **Best single-drawer**: Lakeland Slimline air fryer for £89.99 at Lakeland.
  - **Best for chips**: Philips 5000 Series NA555/09 dual basket steam air fryer for £179.99 at John Lewis.
- Testing included cooking chips and onion rings, assessing performance based on appearance, crispness, and consistency.
- Notable limitations mentioned include button interface challenges and the lower temperature limits on some models.

items.title: Tesla Owners Selling Cars Over Musk's Nazi-style Salutes
items.summary:
- Tesla owners are selling their vehicles in protest of Elon Musk after his controversial Nazi-style salutes during Trump’s inauguration.
- Many enthusiasts express a conflict between their admiration for Tesla cars and disapproval of Musk's political actions and statements.
- Notable owner protests include singing, bumper stickers, and social media campaigns urging others to sell their Teslas.
- Tesla's sales have declined significantly in the U.S. and Europe, with reports of up to 63% drop in some markets, along with stock price volatility.

items.title: If the best defence against AI is more AI, this could be tech’s Oppenheimer moment
items.author: Alexander C Karp, Nicholas W Zapiska
items.summary:
- The article discusses the coupling of AI development with national security concerns, as highlighted by the book *The Technological Republic: Hard Power, Soft Belief and the Future of the West* by Alexander C Karp and Nicholas W Zapiska.
- Karp emphasizes the neglect of technological capabilities in favor of consumer goods by Silicon Valley, arguing for a collaboration with the state similar to that of the Manhattan Project.
- The authors suggest that a more intimate relationship between government and technology is essential for maintaining the United States' global competitive edge, implying the need for technological readiness in a potentially dangerous world.
- Karp believes that using AI is crucial to combating AI abuse, framing it as a necessary evil in the context of national security.

items.title: Read the signs of Trump’s federal firings: AI is coming for private sector jobs too
items.summary:
- Approximately 6,700 workers at the IRS will be laid off, about 8% of the agency's workforce.
- Layoffs coincide with a busy tax season, raising concerns over the processing of millions of tax returns and refunds.
- Upcoming Congressional debates may revise significant tax laws, impacting IRS workload.
- Remaining IRS employees face increased pressure amid reduced staffing and pending tax law changes.
- AI technology is advancing rapidly, potentially replacing many IRS functions and jobs across various sectors.
- Companies like Klarna are replacing human workers with AI, highlighting a growing trend in automation across industries.

items.title: Bitcoin price falls by 17.5% in biggest monthly loss since 2022
items.summary:
- Bitcoin experienced a 17.5% decline in February, marking its largest monthly loss since June 2022.
- The price ended the month at approximately $84,252, hitting a three-month low of about $78,273.
- This drop signifies a technical bear market, with prices now over 20% below the record high of $109,071 set in mid-January.
- The decline is attributed to rising market volatility and concerns over a potential global trade war following Donald Trump's tariff announcements.
- Negative sentiment among traders has been exacerbated by a cyber-attack on the Bybit exchange, resulting in the theft of $1.5 billion in digital assets.
- Experts predict that without concrete regulatory support for cryptocurrencies from the Trump administration, negative market sentiment may persist.

items.title: Black spots, satellites and Elon: new technology could fill Australia’s mobile gaps – but can it be relied on?
items.summary:
- Bernie Byrnes highlights mobile black spots in rural Australia, where reception often fails on highways.
- The Australian government proposes a new legislative obligation for improved mobile coverage, especially for emergencies and disasters.
- New low-earth orbit (LEO) satellite technologies, like Starlink, could enhance mobile services in remote areas.
- Direct-to-device satellite technology allows mobile phones to connect to satellites, as demonstrated during the Los Angeles wildfires.
- The government has not disclosed the cost of the new mobile obligation, with legislation set for 2025 and implementation by late 2027.
- Competition concerns arise as Starlink is currently the sole commercial LEO operator in Australia.
- Local residents express the need for improved mobile coverage for safety and efficient communication, especially in emergencies.
